instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01958: What is 820-01958? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_G3H: What is PP3V3_G3H? PP3V3_G3H is a 3.3v power line that is present when the machine is in a Global System Hardware Off state, and should come on before most other rails so that the USB-C circuitry can be powered for the charger.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.PP1V1_SLPS2R: What is PP1V1_SLPS2R? The PP1V1_SLPS2R power rail in the MacBook schematic provides a 1.1-volt supply in a specific low-power state indicated by the "_SLPS2R" suffix and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP1V2_AWAKE: What is PP1V2_AWAKE? The PP1V2_AWAKE signal in the MacBook schematic is a power rail that provides 1.2 volts and is associated with the machine's awake state and is used for powering the T2 chip..
definitions.PP3V_G3H: What is PP3V_G3H? This is a typo of PP3V3_G3H When you see PP3V_G3H, assume they meant to type PP3V3_G3H.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
I have a Macbook pro in - 820 - 01958 that had water damage around <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>

I'm getting 20v at .07amp with my amp meter


After checking on the forum I've found some info on putting these info DFU etc, though I don't have another machine to test this unfortunately.

I've found one of the R32 coils that I'm getting 0.000 on both sides with diode mode

To confirm, this means the CPU is shorted in most cases right?


I would usually already be confident with my result, though without having correct schematic and board view I thought I would ask. hoping you guys say I'm jumping the gun.

Thanks.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
The CPU core coils show very low values as normal.
You should compare with good similar board; using same generation CPU.
BTW, switch to ohm mode, instead of diode, when you check very low values.

Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
Thanks a bunch for the insight and tip! I'll make sure I do that in the future,

Unfortunately I don't have another known good board here for this one!

Post basic voltages for <CHIP>U7650</CHIP>; pins 23, 12, 13, 22, 29, 21. 

23 = 12.3v
12 = 0v
13 = 0v
22 = 3.3v
29 = 0.3v
21 =0.1v 

Thanks for your help as always

<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
Thanks for your reply. 

I'm unsure how I can check these when we don't have access to the correct boardview file... <CHIP>U7650</CHIP> is similar to other models, though this area isn't :/

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
Thanks, sorry don't mean to waste your time, I had a look before posting just not on here.


<SIGNAL>LDO_CORE</SIGNAL> = 1.5v
<SIGNAL>PMU_LDO3_OUT</SIGNAL> = 1.8v
<SIGNAL>LDO_RTC</SIGNAL> = 1.5v

Thanks again!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
You've forgot 3 important LDO rails.
Look inside <CHIP>U7800</CHIP> notations.

Should be good to check all AWAKE and SLPS2R voltages from the board too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
I understand sorry,

<SIGNAL>PP0V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 0.8v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.8v 
<SIGNAL>PP3V_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.0v
<SIGNAL>PP1V2_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 1.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_G3H</SIGNAL> = 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_AWAKE</SIGNAL> = 3.2v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> = 0.0v
<SIGNAL>PMU_VPUMP</SIGNAL> = 5v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPS2R</SIGNAL> = 1.1v
<SIGNAL>PP1V1_SLPDDR</SIGNAL>= 1.1v
P1V1SLPDDR_RAMP = 3.0v
<SIGNAL>P1V1_SLPDDR_SOCFET_EN</SIGNAL> = 1.8v

Checked all voltages on page 63 incase that I needed those as well. 

Thanks again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01958</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> water damage, now no boot!
threads.message:
T2 doesn't enable S5 state for some reason.
You must try DFU...
